Description: Digital photograph (colour); view of engraved, pecked rock art on rock face showing infilled figures of thirteen humans, one cow, two camels, one automobile, Arabic script and numerous unidentified shapes. All figures upright and facing left, human figures face on. Top (left to right): stick-figure style human figure with unidentified object in hand; unidentified geometric shape; thirteen human figures with arms raised and unidentified objects (bows? quivers?) in hands. Cow bisected by vertical line with u- shaped horns; unidentified objects. Centre (left to right): unidentified shapes; Arabic text (“Ministry of Agriculture Expedition, 1939. Long live Farouk I and long live Sudan”) outline of a car or truck with “1939” on it in East Arabic numerals, “1960” in East Arabic numerals to right; camel. Karkur Talh, Sudan. Scanned
Curator's comments: Detail of 2013.2034.265 Karkur Tahl is the largest wadi (dry seasonal riverbed valley) in the sandstone eastern section of Jebel Uweinat, a granite and sandstone massif on the border of Egypt, Libya and Sudan. Karkur Talh is around 25 km long and lies mostly in Sudan, but partly within Egypt’s borders. There is an abundance of both painted and engraved rock art in shelters in the smaller side wadis. The engravings were first revealed to academia by Ahmed Hassanein in 1923 and a few photographs published in his report on the journey in National Geographic in 1924. A more comprehensive publication of rock art sites in Karkur Talh was made by Prince Kemal el Dine with Abbe Breuil in 1925 following his discovery of a painted cave in Karkur Talh. Further exploration and publications were made by numerous others including renowned explorer Ralph Bagnold’s expedition in 1931, with further exploration from László Almásy and Leo Frobenius in 1933. The largest professional exploration of the massif to date was made in 1968 by a team of Belgian scientists.
Acquisition name: Donated by: Trust for African Rock Art
